condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, I, A, 1 (a) | Description :Maintain, throughout the period of implementation of the Project, aProject Steering Committee. | Due Date :30-Jul-2010
Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, I, A, 1 (b) | Description :Maintain, throughout the period of implementation of the Project, aBudget Committee. | Due Date :30-Jul-2010

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, I, A, 1 (c) | Description : Maintain throughout the period of implementation of the Project aProject Implementation Unit, headed by the recipient's Director General Customs as Project Director, and assisted by a ProjectGeneral Manager. | Due Date :30-Jun-2016
Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, I, B, 1 (a) | Description :Prepare and adopt, a Project Financial Management Manual | Due Date:30-May-2010

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, I, B, 2 (a) | Description :Cause the Budget Committee to prepare and furnish to the Association, byno later than December 20th of each year, commencing on December 20, 2010, a detailed Annual Work Plan. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, II, A, 1 | Description :Recipient shall prepare Annual Project, and shall be furnished to theAssociation not later than one (1) month after the end of theperiod covered by such report. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, II, B, 2 | Description :Prepare and furnish to the Association not later than forty five (45) daysafter the end of each calendar quarter, interim unaudited financial reports for the Project covering the quarter. | Frequency:Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, II, B, 3 | Description :Have its Financial Statements audited each fiscal year of the Recipient, andfurnished to the Association not later than six (6) months after the end of such period. | Frequency :Yearly

title.narrative: Cost savings to business due to Customs Reform

actual.value: Inland Clearance (avg) 87 minutesBorder Clearance (avg) less than 20 minutes

target.value: Average user satisfaction rating of 7 out of 10.

title.narrative: Provision of selected Customs infrastructure to enable modernized operations

target.value: Contracts awarded for at least 8 sub-projects, and agreed Infrastructure works completed

actual.value: On infrastructure development, a total of 14 contracts of various sizes were awarded. Out of these 12 contracts have beencompleted. Only 2 contracts (Construction of Aqina Boundary Wall and Nimroz ICD Truck Parking) are still in progress, and will notbe completed by Project closing date. The main reason for the delay in completion of these two sub-projects were adverse weatherconditions, security related incidents, and delay in vacation of site by other security agencies, well beyond the control of ACD.

title.narrative: Technical assistance to support the development of an adequate regulatory, administrative and institutional framework for Customs

target.value: Studies completed for (i) National Single Window feasibility, (ii) Trade Portal development (iii) Technology equipmentfeasibilities.Experts hired for Legislative review, strengthening of PCA, valuation and risk management and enforcement.ActionPlan for setting up enforcement wing completed

actual.value: The feasibility study for implementing a National Single Window and Trade Information Portal was awarded, and Consultants mobilizedin June. This activity will be transitioned, and undertaken through the on-going Fiscal Performance Improvement Support Project(FSP). Additionally the process to hire technical assistance in the areas of Risk Management, Enforcement, HR and Legal hascommenced.ACD has completed the drafting of regulations and procedures to implement the Cabinet approved HR policy.

title.narrative: Countrywide computerization of Customs Clearance operations

baseline.value: Declaration Processing System (DPS) operational at five locations (i) Kabul ICD, (ii) Kabul Airport, (iii) Herat, (iv) Mazar, (v)Kunduz

target.value: ASYCUDA Operational at 16 Custom officesRisk Management operational at 11 locationsValuation module operational at 6 locations

actual.value: ASYCUDA Declaration Processing System is now operational in 19 Custom offices.Risk Management module is functional in 19 Customoffices.Valuation module is operational in 10 Custom Offices.Entry-exit gate control system is working in 6 Customoffices.International transit has been implemented in 7 corridors.In the current reporting period e-payment system wasimplemented in 6 Custom offices. TIR module was implemented at three locations. Transit module was implemented at Paktia-Kabulcorridor. Link between T1 and DPS modules was created.

title.narrative: Installation of executive information systems for Customs allowing real time monitoring of operations

baseline.value: Executive Information System not available in ACD

target.value: Executive information system installed in MOF, ACD HQ and five regional offices

actual.value: Executive information system installed in ACD. The executive information system has been further improved by including additionalSMS alerts, and additional reports for management. EIS has been rolled out to three key Custom Houses in Jalalabad, Heart andMaazar.

title.narrative: ASYCUDA Inland and international transit operational

baseline.value: Inland transit operational at 5 axis (i) Torkhum-Jalalabad-Kabul, (ii) Islamqala-Herat-Kabul, (iii) Hairatan-Mazar-Kabul, (iv)Sherkhan Bander-Kunduz-Kabul, and (v) Torghundi-Mazar-Kabul.

target.value: Inland and international transit operational at (i) Spinboldak/Vesh-Kandahar-Kabul (Pakistan), (ii) Zaranj/Nimroz-Kandahar-Kabul(Iran), (iii) Aqina-Andkhoi-Mazar-Kabul (Turkmenistan), (iv) Takhar-Kunduz-Kabul (Tajikistan), (v) GhulamKhan/Babraktown-Khost-Kabul(Pakistan), (vi) Millak-Herat/Kandahar-Kabul (Iran), (vii) Eshkashim-Mazar-Kabul (Tajikistan), (viii)Kabul Airport-Kabul Inland Customs.

actual.value: Inland transit was made operational at two more corridor (total 11 corridors) (i) Abu Nasr Farahi-Farah-Kabul corridor, and (ii)Paktia-Kabul Corridor.International transit operational fully covering eight corridors (Pakistan- Uzbekistan,-Tajikistan and-Turkmenistan, Iran - Tajikistan and Turkmenistan - Tajikistan)

Construction of modern data center complete. ICT and other equipment under procurement through FSP..ACD has made decision to hostan off site Disaster Recovery facility in Gibraltar. MoU is expected to be signed between ACD and Gibraltar Customs by July 2018.

title.narrative: Development of possible options for cross border Customs-to-Customs (C2C) Cooperation

baseline.value: No formal C2C cooperation between Afghanistan and its neighboring counties.

target.value: Real time data exchange between Afghan and Tajikistan Customs and Afghan and Pakistan Customs. C2C MoU between Afghanistan and Iransigned.

actual.value: Customs to Customs cooperation. Since last reporting period, the system interface between Iran Customs system and AfghanistanASYCUDA system was created and tested. Data exchange between Afghanistan and Pakistan is delayed due to various reasons, howeverboth sides have committed to complete the process at the earliest. The Bank Team is facilitating a mission to Pakistan within thenest couple of months to finalize the technical modalities. With MoU signed between with Iran, China and Uzbekistan, and real timedata exchange between Afghanistan and Tajikistan implemented, and data exchange between Afghanistan and Iran tested, the projecthas mostly met the end project target.
